title: Convert amounts into first equation
text: Let's use "n" as the amount in pounds of nuts and "c" as the amount in pounds of chocolate chips. The total weight combined is $$20$$ pounds, therefore we can determine that the first equation is $$n+c=20$$
speech: Let's use "n" as the amount in pounds of nuts and "c" as the amount in pounds of chocolate chips. The total weight combined is , 20  pounds, therefore we can determine that the first equation is  n, plus c, is equal to 20

title: Convert amoutn into second equation
text: Because the total amount of money was 20*$7.60 $$=$$ $152 and nuts are $$\$9.00$$ per pound and chocolate chips $2 per pound, we can determine that the second equation is $$9n+2c=152$$

title: Isolate Variable
text: Let's use the first equation to isolate c. With the equation, we can subtract a from both sides to get $$c=20-n$$
speech: Let's use the first equation to isolate c. With the equation, we can subtract a from both sides to get , c is equal to 20 minus n

title: Plug in
text: We can plug in $$c=20-n$$ using the second equation to get $$9n+2\left(20-n\right)=152$$
speech: We can plug in  c is equal to 20 minus, n  using the second equation to get  9 n, plus, 2 times, parentheses 20 minus n,  is equal to 152

title: Solve for a
text: We can determine that the second equation after plugging in "c" would be $$7n+40=152$$. We now isolate the variable "n" and get $$7n=112$$. Then, we can divide both sides by $$7$$ to get $$n=16$$. There are $$16$$ pounds of nuts.

title: Solve for c
text: After solving for "n", we can plug that value into the first equation to get $$16+c=20$$ which we can determine c to be $$4$$.
speech: After solving for "n", we can plug that value into the first equation to get , 16 plus c, is equal to 20  which we can determine c to be  4 .
